I have a wonderful husband who has been/will be by my side no matter what happens. I hope I will be as lucky as you ladies out there--blessed with a bundle of joy!!

Posts.Title: Feel horrible for thinking this. A why me vent. blondie1 SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 11:36AM Z28Femme wrote: I'm 31 years old, recently married  and I live in Baltimore, MD with my husband and 4 dogs. I have no children, but do have cryopreserved embryo's that are waiting for me when I'm done my treatments. I'm newly diagnosed, 2/1/13, with stage IV poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma 7cm mass with mets to the spine, chest wall and liver--ER-/PR-, HER2+. I started chemo on 3/7/13 and will start radiation to spine and chest wall 3/18/13. I do have a family history of breast/colon cancer, but I am the youngest as of yet to get diagnosed.

Posts.Title: Port Placement Z28Femme justjudie

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2013 06:04PM Z28Femme wrote: Thank you everyone for the information, very helpful!! Kay-It's quite alright!! I know that the onc's would have to flush it monthly if it is not in use. If you don't have to pay out of pocket, I think it is worth not being stuck in the arm. Teacher - My port does protrude--looks like a marble under my skin! Even though I had mine put in yesterday, it was used today for a dosing of Taxol. It was a bit uncomfortable being that it's only a day old, but the needle went in soo smoothly! I will have chemo for at least a year and will need labwork done weekly. I'm on a 21 day cycle, with Taxol also on day 8. I am thankful that the cancer treatment center I go to has trained phlebotomist's to access ports. I will not have to get stuck in the arm at all!! Currently I do not have insurance, so all of my treatments are covered under the breast and cervical cancer program of MD. I'm very thankful that there's a program out there that will help people like me!!

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 07:00PM Z28Femme wrote: What keeps me going is knowing that I would like to have a child someday. I was fortunate enough to have completed the fertility process before starting chemo & radiation. I may never experience bearing children or even the birth--but I want a part of my husband and I in this world with us. I've even had a dear friend offer to be my surrogate if I'm not able to carry. It makes my heart swell knowing how selfless some people can be.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 03:00PM - edited May 14, 2013 03:01PM by Z28Femme Thanks everyone for all of the kind wishes. As of right now, I spend a lot of time with my bestie and she has a 7 year old and a 1 year old. I watched both being born and always wanted to experience that same greatness of my own. I do my share of babysitting, but in the end, I go home to a house without a child. I know a lot have those fears of leaving their kids behind and a lot also would give anything to experience a child of their own. It is definately a tough decision to make, and certainly one I will not be thinking about within the next 6 months or so. My recent PET scan showed excellent results, and it only makes me more hopeful for the future. I do understand that I need to concentrate on myself for the time being, but I just can't stop thinking about the "what ifs?" My reproductive organs are still in working order and continuously get my monthly cycle; so I still stand positive that there may be a miracle in the works later down the road! My husband and I have discussed this and he knows how much of a touchy subject it is for me. He will be right by my side with whatever decision I make in the future. Much love to all of you and thank you for your replies. -Bethany
Posts.Title: Children after chemo? Z28Femme Latte

Posts.Content: May 19, 2013 09:48AM Z28Femme wrote: I was stage IV at diagnosis (mets to spine, mediastinum, liver). After 4 tx cycles, they are not talking about surgery for the future. I have great faith in my team of doctors, so I will stand by this! Even though I have pondered what it would be like, hypothetically, after surgery. I've known women that have great trouble lifting their arms/carrying things due to removal of nodes and breats. But on the other hand, am I at risk for lymphedema? I've had 10 biopsies taken of my tumor(s). 5 on the left, 5 on the right with 2 biopsies on right node. Right breast tumor is 7cm (main), also have benign tumor on left side. For now I'm keeping my diseased girls, but who knows for the future!?
Posts.Title: The point of removing breasts at Stage IV? SandyinPa macyhen111

Posts.Content: Z28Femme wrote: So everyone I know is extremely shocked with how well I am taking the news of stage iv breast cancer. I was diagnosed Feb 1st 2013. They are amazed at how well my body is taking the chemo (only 1 cycle, so far), that I've completed my radiation, and just being positive in general with such a serious disease. Life doesn't feel too different, except I cannot lift heavy things and I'm too tired to get to the gym. I'm still working full time, minus the days where I have appointments/chemo. Could it possibly be that I am still in denial? Has anyone been here, done that? How long before life will slap me in the face and bring me back to reality? I know that I'm not alone here! Initial Stage IV diagnosis, mets to spine, chest wall, liver..Live for today, as we do not know what tomorrow may bring! ~Bethany www.caringbridge.org/visit/bet... Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 08:52AM Z28Femme wrote: Thank you all for your replies! It sounds awful, but I'm glad I am not alone on this one. I was starting to think there was something wrong with me! I will heed your advice, as it sounds very good. I try to think about only today; as tomorrow is a different story with a different ending... On a different note, I had round 2 of chemo today (perjeta,herceptin,taxol). I'm currently feeling okay--just tired and my legs feel heavy. I hope I will still feel okay to make it to work in the morning! Thanks again everyone for your input! :)
Posts.Title: Still in denial? Z28Femme Z28Femme

Posts.Content: Z28Femme wrote: Had my PET/CT yesterday and my onc is very pleased! She is dropping Taxol from my treatment. So, I will only do chemo on day 1 on my 21 day cycle instead of day one and day 8. I am keeping Perjeta/Herceptin for at least another year--if not forever. Anyone else on the same page here? She also mentioned some of my SE's may decrease (hair regrowth/fatigue will get better). I'm very happy with the news but will continue to keep my fingers crossed. Will get rescanned with echo every 3 months. -Beth Initial Stage IV diagnosis, mets to spine, chest wall, liver..Live for today, as we do not know what tomorrow may bring! ~Bethany www.caringbridge.org/visit/bet... Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 11:52AM Z28Femme wrote: I did not know Lynn, but my condolences go out to her family and friends. It is always hard to lose a loved one--but now she is free of this disease and watching over us from above. May you rest in peace Lynn. Bethany
Posts.Title: lynn1 bhd1 Leah_S

Posts.Content: May 30, 2013 07:57PM Z28Femme wrote: Thank you everyone for your great responses! I haven't had surgery and probably will not anytime soon. My lymph nodes were originally positive at dx, PET scan showed chemo working and the nodes weren't "lit up" on the imaging. My onc is aware of this but doesn't seem too concerned about the swelling. I had an ultrasound done about a month ago to rule out blood clots, which came back negative. I have had radiation to the spine and mediastinum previously, but not the breast. I will most certainly check out the lymphedema board to gain more knowledge and will also touch base with the onc again to see her opinion of it. More fatigue has set in the deeper into the chemo cycles I go. I started my 5th cycle of p/h/t today with a taxol treatment on day 8. Onc states at least another year left, unless toxicity develops. I usually sleep it off in the room right after getting the benedryl (kicks my butt no matter how hard I try and fight it!). I've lost about 65% of my hair, eyebrows, eyelashes; leg hair is steadily growing (thought I would be off the hook with shaving by now). I've gained 15 pounds since being diagnosed on 2/1/13; stopped going to the gym from lack of energy and the steroids are not helping. I still have my appetite and taste is somewhat normal. My labs come back great (like a normal person) each week and my onc and nurse are very happy to see that. I'm working full time still, as long as I can handle it. I am scheduled to see a dermatologist June 18th to evaluate this acne rash that I have on my face, back, neck and chest. I do not have any nausea, but still taking medication for it just in case. Still get back pain where the lesion is from time to time. I've noticed a giant brain fog a lot of the time. I blame it on the drugs.
Posts.Title: Swelling Anyone? Z28Femme Z28Femme

Posts.Content: Z28Femme wrote: I'm 31 and do not have children yet. I went through the whole fertility process and have 4 embryos frozen. My question is, has anyone gone through something similar? And how long did you have to wait...were you able to conceive...did you use a surrogate...was it hard raising a child after your treatments? All of these questions keep playing through my mind as I watch everyone around me raise their beautiful children! I'm going crazy here while my biological clock is ticking! I knew I should've had kids 10 years ago...
